p: Circulating passive antibodies (primarily IgG), acquired with colostrum, protect the neonate against systemic, however not the intestinal, infection (Hooper and Haelterman 1966a; Saif and Sestak 2006). Between the first 7Â days of lactation, IgA prevails in milk and IgG reduces. Researchers have reviewed the mechanisms of passive immunity to TGEV infection (Saif and Sestak 2006; Chattha et al. 2015; Saif and Jackwood 1990; Saif and Bohl 1979). Swine recovered from TGE spread passive immunity to their suckling pigs with colostrum or milk (lactogenic immunity) containing TGEV virus-neutralising antibodies (Hooper and Haelterman 1966a) that nullify the ingested TGEV in the intestinal lumen. This is accomplished naturally when piglets feed on immune mother regularly or experimentally by constant feeding of antiserum.
